reviews.text: Good little station when you don't want to have to walk to Reading Main, only down point is that disabled and pram access is incredible poor lovely guy that works in the ticket office always has a smile and is very pleasant

Completely rubbish station in almost every way. Limited seating, rubbish shelter, ticket machines on one side only and a make shift temporary exit that really should've been completed by now and should offer step free access to the street.

Trains towards Newbury and Basingstoke stop nowhere near the station entrance.
Cold and tiny but functional. When it's raining, you might want to stand under the bridge but don't, it leaks and you'll get wet. Good fun though.
A small but old station convenient for commuters to/from this peculiar part of Reading. Probably don't leave your bike here

This is probably one of the most unfriendly wheelchair user train stations I have come across thus far. There is no facility whatsoever to assist the wheelchair user. There is no lift system in place to assist the disabled person to come into the station and furthermore cross over from platform 2 to platform 1. This station is highly not recommended for the disabled or wheelchair user, there will be no-one here to help you. This station, from what I can see is not manned, and whilst I was there waiting for the Reading train to arrive, a member of staff ( I shall presume) unlocked the door to an office area on platform two and locked themselves in there. There are CCV cameras fitted in the station platforms, with a very old bridge crossing over to platform one. There are no adequate shelter rooms for bad weather available and this station does not have the appearance "its safe" especially at night. That said, this station does not have any WI-Fi service and it is located next door to Aldi.
